note: 47 reference builds from the Savage Worlds core rulebook.

vehicles.name: Bicycle
vehicles.notes: The bicycle is invisible. Nobody notices one more cyclist on a city street, which makes it the perfect surveillance and courier vehicle for low-tech campaigns. In chase scenes, she squeezes through gaps no car can follow — alleys, stairwells, crowded markets. 50% of shots hit the rider rather than the vehicle.

vehicles.name: Carriage
vehicles.notes: The carriage is your chase vehicle for historical and fantasy campaigns. Stagecoach robberies, runaway horses, rooftop leaps onto the luggage rack — she exists to create cinematic moments. Horse-drawn, so she stops when the horses do.

vehicles.name: Early Car
vehicles.notes: The Model T generation. Slow, temperamental, and revolutionary. She puts your campaign on wheels for the first time — Prohibition rum-runners, early pulp adventures, the first getaway cars. Unreliable enough to create complications at the worst possible moment.

vehicles.name: Street Bike
vehicles.notes: The street bike is your urban pursuit vehicle. She splits lanes, she threads traffic, she fits where cars can't follow. The rider is exposed — 50% of shots hit them rather than the bike. That vulnerability is the price of agility.

vehicles.name: Dirt Bike
vehicles.notes: The dirt bike goes where roads don't. She's the jungle recon vehicle, the desert patrol bike, the mountain courier. Four-wheel drive equivalent for two wheels — she ignores terrain that stops wheeled vehicles cold.

vehicles.name: Compact Car
vehicles.notes: The compact car is your default civilian vehicle. Every NPC drives one, every parking lot is full of them, every car chase starts or ends with one. Mechanically unremarkable, which is exactly the point — she's the baseline everything else is measured against.

vehicles.name: Mid-Sized Car
vehicles.notes: The family sedan. She carries more passengers and gear than the compact, handles roughly the same, and blends into traffic just as easily. The car your players borrow, steal, or commandeer when they need to move without attracting attention.

vehicles.name: Minivan
vehicles.notes: The minivan carries a full party plus gear. She's the team vehicle for modern campaigns — the thing everyone piles into when the job starts. Not fast, not tough, but she holds everyone and their equipment in one vehicle.

vehicles.name: SUV
vehicles.notes: The SUV bridges civilian comfort and rough terrain capability. Four-wheel drive gets her off-road where sedans can't follow. She's the vehicle of choice for private security, rural law enforcement, and players who expect trouble outside city limits.

vehicles.name: Sports Car
vehicles.notes: The sports car wins chases through speed and handling. She's fast on straights, nimble in corners, and utterly useless off-road or in bad weather. The vehicle your players lust after and the one that gets them into trouble.

vehicles.name: Semi-Truck
vehicles.notes: The semi-truck is your convoy centrepiece and your roadblock. She can't manoeuvre, she can't hide, and she takes a long time to stop. But she carries anything, tows anything, and at highway speed she's an unstoppable battering ram. Trailer: Size 7, Toughness 14(2).

vehicles.name: WW2 Jeep
vehicles.notes: The jeep goes everywhere and carries everything. She's the workhorse of military campaigns from WWII to Vietnam — reconnaissance, command vehicle, ambulance, weapons platform. Open-topped and lightly armoured, which means the crew is always one burst away from disaster. Four-wheel drive.

vehicles.name: M4 Sherman
vehicles.notes: The workhorse of the Allied armoured forces. She wasn't the best tank of the war — the Germans outgunned her routinely — but there were always more Shermans. Use her as the reliable, available option that wins through numbers and logistics rather than individual superiority. Heavy Armor, Tracked.

vehicles.name: M5A1 Stuart
vehicles.notes: The Stuart is your light tank — fast, undergunned, and used for reconnaissance rather than direct engagement. She scouts ahead of the main force, finds the enemy, and calls in the Shermans. Players driving Stuarts should feel the tension of bringing a light tank to a heavy fight. Heavy Armor, Tracked.

vehicles.name: T-34/76
vehicles.notes: The T-34 changed tank warfare. Her sloped armour deflected shots that would penetrate a flat-faced Sherman, and she was simple enough to build in staggering numbers. The backbone of the Soviet armoured force and the benchmark for medium tank design. Heavy Armor, Sloped Armor (front), Tracked.

vehicles.name: Pz IVJ
vehicles.notes: The Panzer IV was Germany's reliable medium tank — not as famous as the Tiger, not as advanced as the Panther, but available in numbers and effective across the entire war. She's the opponent your players face most often in a European theatre campaign. Heavy Armor, Tracked.

vehicles.name: Pz VI Tiger II
vehicles.notes: The King Tiger is your named threat. She outguns everything the Allies field and her frontal armour shrugs off most anti-tank weapons. Use her as a boss encounter — the players hear her coming, they plan around her, and they need a clever approach because a straight fight is suicide. Heavy Armor, Tracked.

vehicles.name: M1A1 Abrams
vehicles.notes: The modern benchmark for main battle tanks. Her combination of composite armour, stabilised gun, and thermal imaging makes her dominant in open terrain. Use her to show players what modern military hardware can do — and to remind them that even the best tank is vulnerable in cities. Heavy Armor, Night Vision, Tracked.

vehicles.name: M2 Bradley
vehicles.notes: The Bradley is an infantry fighting vehicle — she carries troops and fights alongside them. Her autocannon shreds light vehicles and her TOW missiles threaten tanks. The players either ride in her or face her, and both experiences should feel dangerous. Heavy Armor, Night Vision, Tracked.

vehicles.name: T-72 MBT
vehicles.notes: The T-72 is the world's most exported tank. She shows up everywhere — every regional conflict, every arms deal, every third-world army. Not as capable as Western designs but available, affordable, and dangerous enough. Heavy Armor, Tracked.

vehicles.name: T-80 MBT
vehicles.notes: The T-80 is the Soviet answer to the Abrams — faster, lower-profile, and equipped with reactive armour. She represents the top tier of opposition for Cold War and modern campaigns. Heavy Armor, Night Vision, Tracked.

vehicles.name: BTR-70 APC
vehicles.notes: The BTR-70 carries infantry into combat and provides fire support with her turret-mounted weapons. She swims rivers without preparation, which changes the tactical map — obstacles that stop wheeled vehicles don't stop a BTR. Amphibious, 4WD, Heavy Armor.

vehicles.name: Hover Tank (SWADE)
vehicles.notes: The hover tank represents the next generation of armoured warfare. She ignores terrain, crosses water without slowing, and positions faster than any tracked vehicle. The trade-off is that hover vehicles can't dig in — she fights on the move or not at all. Heavy Armor, Hover, Night Vision.

vehicles.name: Hover APC (SWADE)
vehicles.notes: The hover APC delivers troops across any terrain at speed. She's the future of mechanised infantry — rivers, rubble, swamp, and rough ground are no longer obstacles. Heavy Armor, Hover.

vehicles.name: Biplane (Civilian)
vehicles.notes: The biplane is your inter-war and pulp adventure aircraft. She's slow enough that the players can shoot pistols from the cockpit, low enough to barnstorm, and fragile enough that every bullet matters. Open cockpit, wind in your face, goggles and scarves.

vehicles.name: Cessna Skyhawk
vehicles.notes: The Cessna is your civilian light aircraft. She's the plane the players charter, steal, or escape in. Simple to fly, cheap to hire, and she lands on dirt strips that would destroy anything bigger. The most produced aircraft in history for a reason.

vehicles.name: Helicopter (Civilian)
vehicles.notes: The civilian helicopter's unique ability is hover and vertical landing. She doesn't need a runway. Use her for medical evacuation, news coverage, executive transport, and dramatic rooftop extractions. VTOL.

vehicles.name: Learjet
vehicles.notes: The Learjet is your fast long-range transport. She gets the players across continents in hours, and her presence tells them something about whoever owns it — money, connections, urgency. She's also a beautiful target sitting on a runway.

vehicles.name: Space Shuttle
vehicles.notes: The shuttle is your near-future and hard sci-fi reference point. She demonstrates that size and Toughness don't always correlate with combat power — the shuttle is large but fragile, designed for a specific mission rather than a fight.

vehicles.name: B-17 Flying Fortress
vehicles.notes: The Flying Fortress is your strategic bomber and your crew survival scenario. She carries ten men, she bristles with defensive guns, and she has to hold formation through flak and fighters for hours. Every mission is a survival horror session at 25,000 feet.

vehicles.name: Bf-109
vehicles.notes: The Messerschmitt is Germany's primary fighter across the entire war. She's fast, she climbs well, and her cannon armament hits hard. The opposition your players face in every European air combat scenario from the Battle of Britain to Berlin.

vehicles.name: P-51 Mustang
vehicles.notes: The Mustang is the best all-round fighter of the war. She escorts bombers to Berlin and back, she dogfights anything the Luftwaffe sends up, and she strafes ground targets on the way home. The player character's fighter of choice.

vehicles.name: Japanese Zero
vehicles.notes: The Zero trades armour for agility. She turns inside anything the Allies fly, which makes her lethal in a dogfight — until the first bullet hits, because she has no armour and no self-sealing fuel tanks. Glass cannon in aircraft form.

vehicles.name: Spitfire Mk IIA
vehicles.notes: The Spitfire is Britain's finest. She matches the Bf-109 in speed, outturns it at most altitudes, and her elliptical wing is the most recognisable silhouette of the war. The Battle of Britain in one aircraft.

vehicles.name: AH-64 Apache
vehicles.notes: The Apache is your modern attack helicopter — she finds targets with her sensor suite, kills them with Hellfire missiles, and moves on before anyone can shoot back. Use her to demonstrate the terrifying gap between infantry and modern air power. Helicopter, Night Vision.

vehicles.name: AV-8B Harrier
vehicles.notes: The Harrier operates from roads, clearings, and ships too small for conventional aircraft. Her VTOL capability means she can be anywhere the enemy doesn't expect close air support. Slow for a jet, devastating for anything on the ground. VTOL.

vehicles.name: F-15 Eagle
vehicles.notes: The Eagle has never been shot down in air-to-air combat. She's the benchmark for air superiority fighters — fast, well-armed, and equipped with sensors that let her fight beyond visual range. The thing your players hear about but never want to see. Night Vision.

vehicles.name: SU-27
vehicles.notes: The Flanker is the Soviet answer to the F-15 — arguably more manoeuvrable, certainly more dramatic in appearance, and equipped to fight at every range. She represents peer-level opposition for any modern air combat campaign. Night Vision.

vehicles.name: UH-1 Huey
vehicles.notes: The Huey is the sound of the Vietnam War. Her distinctive rotor beat tells everyone — friendly and hostile — that she's coming. She carries troops, she evacuates wounded, she provides fire support, and she defines the helicopter warfare era. Helicopter.

vehicles.name: Galleon
vehicles.notes: The galleon is your Age of Sail warship and your pirate campaign flagship. She carries dozens of guns, a crew of hundreds, and enough provisions for months at sea. She's a floating fortress, a mobile settlement, and a slow-moving target for anything faster. Heavy Armor.

vehicles.name: Galley
vehicles.notes: The galley is your ancient and medieval warship. Oars give her independence from wind — she moves when and where the captain commands, which makes her the dominant naval platform from Greece to Lepanto. Her ram is as dangerous as her weapons. Heavy Armor, Oars+Sails.

vehicles.name: Hydrofoil
vehicles.notes: The hydrofoil lifts out of the water at speed, reducing drag and dramatically increasing velocity. She's your fast patrol and intercept vessel for coastal operations — faster than conventional boats, more agile, and harder to hit at speed.

vehicles.name: Patrol Boat, River
vehicles.notes: The PBR is your brown-water navy vessel — rivers, estuaries, coastlines. She's small enough to navigate shallow waterways that would ground larger craft, and armed enough to suppress fire from both banks. The Vietnam riverine warfare workhorse. Heavy Armor.

vehicles.name: PT Boat
vehicles.notes: The PT boat is your fast attack craft — she closes with the enemy at speed, launches torpedoes, and gets out before the return fire finds her. Small crew, high risk, enormous potential reward if the torpedoes hit. JFK commanded one. Heavy Armor.

vehicles.name: Rowboat
vehicles.notes: The rowboat is your insertion vehicle. She's silent, she's invisible against a dark shoreline, and she carries a small team to wherever they need to be without alerting anyone. Also the thing that's between your players and drowning when the ship sinks.

vehicles.name: Speed Boat
vehicles.notes: The speedboat is your modern chase vehicle on water. Fast, agile, and fragile — she's the equivalent of a sports car on the open sea. Drug runners, coast guard, and players who need to be somewhere coastal in a hurry.

vehicles.name: Small Yacht
vehicles.notes: The yacht is a location, not a chase vehicle. She's where the party happens, where the deal goes down, where the villain entertains guests while the players infiltrate from the waterline. Comfortable, expensive, and conspicuous.
